bioghist.p: The Tri-State Bible Conference was founded in 1929 by Dr. Abraham L. Latham, a pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church of Chester (Pennsylvania) and other members of the Chester Presbytery and lay community as a reaction to what they saw as the increasing liberalization of values and standards within the Presbyterian Church. The Conference was concerned with the training and education of young adults and was conceived as an alternative to the existing summer youth programs that the area Presbyteries offered -- one which emphasized fundamentalist teachings and missionary and evangelical work within the context of Presbyterianism. Despite its Presbyterian origins, the corporation was never official connected to or recognized by the Philadelphia Presbytery or the Committee on Christian Education. During the late 1950s and early 1960s, some attempts were made to unite the Tri-State Bible Conference with the Philadelphia Presbytery. These attempts, failed, however, in part due to friction caused by what was seen by some as the Conference's basically fundamentalist/evangelical stance on religion. Since 1970 the Conference has met each summer at Hilltop Ranch in Colora, Maryland.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Tri-State Bible Conference. Materials include: minutes; brochures, conference programs and flyers; slides and photographs; lists of delegates, 1944-1974: correspondence and lists of delegates, 1975-1979; correspondence, by-laws, and certificate of incorporation, 1945; correspondence related to the relationship of Tri-State to the camping programs of the Philadelphia Presbytery, 1955-1962; a two volume history of the Tri-State Bible Conference, 1929-1958; a 1969 Tri-State publicity reel to reel audio tape; several reels of 8mm movie film; printing blocks for the Tri-State Bible Conference; and an index card file of addresses of Board of Directors and members.
